sub_title: Policy Advisor / Researcher / Consultant International Water Policy and Delta Management
summary: Martijn van Staveren has a background in International Land and Water Management. His PhD, obtained at Wageningen UR, is a policy analysis comparing flood management policies in the Netherlands, Bangladesh and Vietnam. He has been working with various organizations and institutes to support international partnerships and collaborations in the Dutch and international water sector. He works at IHE Delft as coordinator of the Netherlands IHP-HWRP committee, a science-policy platform that defines the Dutch thematic priorities and collaborations in the UNESCO and WMO water research programmes. He has an interest in water knowledge co-development, water history and science-policy interaction.

projects: [{'title': 'All-risk', 'date': {'start': {'month': 8, 'day': None, 'year': 2017}, 'end': {'month': 2, 'day': None, 'year': 2021}}, 'description': None, 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Martijn', 'last_name': 'van Staveren PhD', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Policy Advisor / Researcher / Consultant International Water Policy and Delta Management'}]}, {'title': 'Communities and institutions for flood resilience', 'date': {'start': {'month': 2, 'day': None, 'year': 2012}, 'end': {'month': 8, 'day': None, 'year': 2017}}, 'description': 'As full flood protection is neither sustainable nor possible it is crucial to reduce the impact of floods on people and economies in both poor and rich countries through the development of appropriate strategies to reduce flood exposure and vulnerability. This WOTRO IP funded  research programme will assess and compare the strategies and policies of governments, professionals and communities to reduce flood risk and vulnerability in the Bangladeshi and Dutch Deltas, to contribute to poverty reduction through the strengthening of institutional and community capacities to manage moderate floods and increase resilience to extreme floods. The research will examine how different communities develop, adopt, implement and modify flood risk management policies in the two deltas, and will enhance mutual learning between Bangladesh and the Netherlands. This will yield new frameworks and tools that will give insights into levels of vulnerability and resilience to flooding and how to reduce flood risk-exposure.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Martijn', 'last_name': 'van Staveren PhD', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Policy Advisor / Researcher / Consultant International Water Policy and Delta Management'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Arjen', 'last_name': 'Zegwaard', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Program Director at Wageningen University & Research'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Flip', 'last_name': 'Wester', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Independent researcher water, climate, mountains, deltas, river basins, assessments, ICIMOD Fellow, IWRA Fellow, IPCC WGII Lead Author'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Jeroen', 'last_name': 'Warner', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Associate Professor of Disaster Studies, Social Sciences Group, Wageningen University'}, {'type': 'nonStandardizedContributor', 'first_name': None, 'last_name': None, 'name': 'Arthur Petersen', 'headline': None}, {'type': 'nonStandardizedContributor', 'first_name': None, 'last_name': None, 'name': 'Jan van tatenhove', 'headline': None}]}]

All-risk is funded by NWO-STW and actively cooperates with the Flood Protection Programme in the Netherlands, with the objective to meet new flood safety standards.', 'title': 'Postdoc, Environmental Policy Group', 'employment_type': 'Part-time'}, {'location': 'Wageningen', 'date': {'start': {'month': 2, 'day': None, 'year': 2012}, 'end': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2017}}, 'company': 'Wageningen University & Research', 'description': "My PhD dissertation compares flood risk management policies in three typical delta countries: Bangladesh, Vietnam and the Netherlands. In each of these low-lying deltas, different approaches towards flood management are being followed. Remarkably, however, is that there is one commonality: in each delta, de-poldering and river restoration is taking place along rivers and coasts. Ideas about 'living with water' and nature-based solutions support this, but there are various other drivers and barriers to such flood management interventions. The dissertation analyses similarities and differences across three country based cases.
